snippet: Hours before Robert James Campbell, a Texas inmate convicted of murder, was scheduled to die, a federal court said his claim of mental disability must first be reviewed.
abstract: Federal appeals court grants stay of execution for condemned Texas inmate Robert James Campbell so courts can review his claim that he is mentally disabled; Supreme Court has long banned the execution of those whom the law refers to as mentally retarded, and has said that an IQ of under 'approximately 70' indicates retardation.

byline.original: By MANNY FERNANDEZ and JOHN SCHWARTZ
byline.contributor: Manny Fernandez reported from Huntsville, and John Schwartz from New York.

lead_paragraph: Hours before Robert James Campbell, a Texas inmate convicted of murder, was scheduled to die, a federal court said his claim of mental disability must first be reviewed.

headline.main: Appeals Court Grants Stay of Execution in Texas Based on Mental Disability Claim
headline.print_headline: Appeals Court Grants Stay of Execution in Texas Based on Mental Disability Claim
